items.practice: Use Plan Mode for complex tasks to generate a detailed, editable plan before executing code changes.
items.why_it_matters: Cursor’s Plan Mode enables the agent to analyse the codebase, ask clarifying questions and produce a sequenced plan. An upfront plan reduces back‑and‑forth, controls the scope and makes tasks reproducible.
how_to_apply: Trigger Plan Mode (Shift+Tab) or slash command before starting a significant change.
Answer the agent’s clarifying questions and revise the generated plan in markdown; break large goals into smaller steps and save the plan to the repository if relevant.
Once satisfied, ask the agent to execute each step using the preferred model (e.g., Sonnet 4.5 or Gemini 2.5) and monitor progress.

usage_example.context: Refactoring a legacy billing module across multiple files.
steps: Open Plan Mode and describe the overall goal: refactor billing to use a new payment API.
Respond to questions about existing file locations and confirm the new API version.
Edit the proposed steps (e.g., update API client, adjust tests, deprecate old functions) and save the plan.
Run the plan; the agent executes tasks step‑by‑step using the chosen model.
usage_example.expected_outcome: A structured refactoring plan is executed with fewer revisions and clearer progress tracking.
usage_example.snippet: // Refactor billing module: update PaymentService, modify tests in @Folders/tests/billing, remove legacy endpoints.

checks: Plan document exists and is versioned
caveats: Plan Mode adds initial overhead; use only for multi‑step tasks
Overly broad plans still require refinement

items.practice: Use @Files, @Folders and @Docs to anchor queries to specific files, directories or documentation instead of the entire repository.
items.why_it_matters: Large context windows slow responses and can introduce irrelevant information. Pinpointing the exact files or folders tells the model where to look, resulting in faster and more accurate answers.
how_to_apply: When asking the agent to modify or analyse code, include @Files/path and @Folders/path to constrain its view to the relevant modules.
Use @Docs to add third‑party or internal documentation (e.g., API references) so the model follows your stack’s conventions.
Summarise noisy sections rather than pasting entire files; provide only the necessary context.

steps: Invoke the agent with: ‘Refactor @Files/src/auth.ts to simplify branching. Consider helpers in @Folders/src/utils.’
Add @Docs/our-auth-guidelines.md to supply style conventions.
Review the proposed change and ensure it adheres to the guidelines.
usage_example.expected_outcome: The agent proposes targeted refactoring within the specified file and uses the documentation for consistency.

caveats: Including outdated docs can mislead the model
Too many references may increase token usage

items.practice: Break complex requests into focused sessions and limit the context window to improve performance and relevance.
items.why_it_matters: Long sessions with broad goals increase token usage and lead to off‑target suggestions. Structuring sessions keeps the agent’s attention on one goal at a time and produces cleaner diffs.
how_to_apply: Before invoking the agent, decompose the overall objective into smaller, sequential tasks (e.g., update one module or API at a time).
Run each task in its own agent session of 15–30 minutes; avoid mixing unrelated changes.
Disable continuous analysis on the main branch and enable agents on feature branches to control scope.

usage_example.context: Adding logging and caching to an analytics service.
steps: Create a feature branch and run an agent session to add structured logging to @Files/src/analytics.ts.
After reviewing and committing that diff, start a new session to introduce caching using @Folders/src/cache.
Finally merge the feature branch after tests pass.
usage_example.expected_outcome: Each change is isolated, easier to review and less likely to introduce drift.

checks: Tasks are scoped to one module
caveats: Requires discipline and may slow momentum on tight deadlines
Too many small commits may clutter history

items.practice: Define project rules (e.g., allowed file types, naming conventions, search requirements, patch size limits) in version‑controlled `.cursorrules` files and use custom slash commands to apply them.
items.why_it_matters: Rules constrain the agent’s modifications, ensuring consistency, preventing unintentional changes and reducing hallucinations. Version control makes rule changes auditable and shareable across teams.
how_to_apply: Create a `.cursorrules` file or a `.cursor/rules` directory specifying naming patterns, allowed languages, maximum patch sizes, search guidelines (semantic and grep), and restrictions on running dev servers or altering build files.
Commit the rules to your repository so they are automatically loaded when agents run.
For manual runs, create a custom command (e.g., `/apply-rules`) that reads the active file and inserts its content along with rules into the prompt so the agent uses them.

usage_example.context: Maintaining consistency in a React project.
steps: Write rules: use Tailwind colours from theme.js; require named exports; prefer pnpm; search using both semantic and grep; limit patches to 200 lines; forbid running `npm run dev` unless asked.
Add them to `.cursorrules` and commit.
Run `/apply-rules` before asking the agent to add a new feature; the agent adheres to the conventions.
usage_example.expected_outcome: Generated code respects style and tool requirements, and the agent does not modify forbidden files.

caveats: Changing rules requires re‑indexing and may confuse the agent
Rules enforcement may not cover all edge cases

items.practice: Adopt test‑driven development by asking Cursor to write tests first, then implement or refactor code to satisfy them.
items.why_it_matters: Writing tests up front clarifies requirements, exposes edge cases and guides the AI to generate production‑ready implementations. It also provides an objective way to verify generated code and catch regressions.
how_to_apply: Describe the desired functionality and instruct the agent to generate unit or integration tests using frameworks relevant to your stack (e.g., Jest, pytest).
Run the tests locally; they will fail initially since the implementation is missing.
Ask the agent to implement the functionality to satisfy the tests and iteratively refine until all tests pass.

usage_example.context: Adding a new endpoint to a Flask API.
steps: Ask the agent: ‘Write pytest tests for a `/status` endpoint returning app health metrics.’
Run the tests and confirm failures.
Request the implementation of the endpoint with proper error handling and update tests accordingly.
Re‑run tests until they pass.
usage_example.expected_outcome: The endpoint is implemented with confidence, guided by tests that capture expected behaviour.

caveats: Poorly written tests lead to weak implementations
Time‑consuming for trivial features

items.practice: Review diffs carefully and limit patch sizes to ensure safe, minimal edits.
items.why_it_matters: LLM‑generated changes can be broad or intrusive. Reviewing diffs and capping patch sizes prevents unintended modifications and keeps Git history readable.
how_to_apply: When using the agent for multi‑file refactors, instruct it to show diffs before applying. Do not auto‑apply changes without inspection.
Specify a maximum patch size in your rules (e.g., 200 lines) and restrict changes to selected folders.
Commit changes in logical chunks and write meaningful messages.

usage_example.context: Migrating from Moment.js to Day.js in a large codebase.
steps: Set a patch limit in `.cursorrules`: `max_patch_size: 200`.
Run the agent with the task: ‘Replace Moment.js imports in @Folders/src/components with Day.js; propose diffs.’
Review the proposed diffs; accept or reject each chunk; commit approved changes.
Repeat across modules until migration completes.
usage_example.expected_outcome: The migration occurs through controlled, reviewable diffs, avoiding sweeping, hard‑to‑review patches.

caveats: Limiting patch size may require more manual sessions
Agents sometimes ignore patch size instructions

items.practice: Configure background agents to run on feature branches with specific rules and monitor their reliability.
items.why_it_matters: Background agents can continuously review pull requests, enforce security rules and suggest fixes. However, misconfiguration or unstable early releases may lead to unexpected behaviour.
how_to_apply: Create a feature branch for each feature or bug fix and enable a background agent configured with your `.cursorrules` to monitor that branch.
Specify tasks for the agent such as linting, vulnerability scanning or style enforcement, and limit its scope to avoid acting on unrelated code.
Regularly check agent logs for errors; if agents misbehave or degrade, disable them temporarily and wait for stable updates or patches.

usage_example.context: Automating security checks on pull requests in a fintech project.
steps: Define a background agent that triggers on new PRs against the `payments` branch and runs static analysis with your rules.
Set the agent to comment with findings and propose patches but not auto‑merge.
Monitor its output; if you notice repeated failures or irrelevant comments, adjust the rules or disable until updates are released.
usage_example.expected_outcome: Security scans run automatically on feature branches without blocking unrelated development, and misbehaving agents are contained.

caveats: Early Cursor 2.0 background agents experienced reliability issues
Agents may consume resources on local machines

items.practice: Use the built‑in browser or @Docs to reference official documentation and keep third‑party docs version‑aligned with your project.
items.why_it_matters: Reliable documentation anchors the model’s responses to authoritative sources, reducing hallucinations and ensuring that generated code follows correct APIs.
how_to_apply: Add relevant external docs (e.g., Next.js, Prisma) via @Docs and specify the version to match your project.
When uncertain about library usage, open the in‑editor browser to search official docs instead of relying on generic internet answers.
Regularly update or remove outdated docs from your settings to prevent mixing versions.

usage_example.context: Implementing a feature using Prisma ORM.
steps: Attach Prisma v5 documentation using @Docs/prisma-5.x before asking the agent to generate queries.
Open the browser to confirm details such as relation definitions.
In prompts, reference specific sections using @Docs so the model uses the correct syntax.
usage_example.expected_outcome: Generated code aligns with the exact version of the library and reduces errors from outdated examples.

caveats: Managing multiple docs can clutter settings
External sites may have restrictive terms

items.practice: Enable privacy mode, restrict indexing to non‑sensitive directories and apply security patches promptly.
items.why_it_matters: Cursor uses external AI services. Privacy mode prevents code from leaving your machine, and limiting the index reduces exposure of secrets. Staying current with patches mitigates known vulnerabilities.
how_to_apply: Turn on Privacy Mode in settings; this runs the model in an isolated container and stops snippets from being sent to remote servers.
Exclude configuration files, environment secrets and private keys in your `.cursorrules` or `.cursorignore` so they are never indexed or proposed for editing.
Monitor security advisories (e.g., CVE‑2025‑59944, CVE‑2025‑54135/36) and update Cursor promptly to patched versions.

usage_example.context: Working on a payment gateway containing API keys.
steps: Activate Privacy Mode before indexing the project.
Add `.env` and `config/keys` folders to `.cursorignore` and rules for exclusion.
After a security bulletin about a case‑sensitivity bug, upgrade Cursor to the patched version and verify that the vulnerability is mitigated.
usage_example.expected_outcome: Sensitive files remain local, unauthorized code execution is prevented and the project benefits from the latest security fixes.

caveats: Privacy Mode disables background agents that need remote resources
Overly restrictive ignores may hinder indexing and suggestions

items.practice: Stay informed about Cursor vulnerabilities (e.g., CurXecute, MCPoison) and adjust workflows to mitigate prompt injection risks.
items.why_it_matters: Recent CVEs revealed that adversaries could inject malicious commands via configuration files or MCP servers. Understanding these risks helps you harden your environment and avoid exploits.
how_to_apply: Review advisory notes (e.g., CVE‑2025‑54135/54136) and understand the attack vectors such as case‑insensitive file systems and Slack‑based MCP servers.
Disable or tightly control remote MCP servers; verify the origin of any external prompts or commands before accepting changes.
Normalise file paths in your environment and apply vendor‑provided patches that close injection paths.

usage_example.context: Using MCP servers to run code generation through Slack.
steps: Read Tenable’s FAQs on CVE‑2025‑54135/36 to understand how prompt injections can modify `mcp.json`.
Limit Slack integration to trusted workspaces and disable automatic command execution.
After applying the patch, test that remote prompts cannot alter configuration files with case variations.
usage_example.expected_outcome: MCP usage is secure, reducing the risk of remote code execution and unauthorized configuration changes.

caveats: Requires continual monitoring of security advisories
May limit collaborative features relying on MCP

items.practice: Select the appropriate model for each task and take advantage of Composer and multi‑agent parallelism to optimize speed and quality.
items.why_it_matters: Models vary in context length, cost and reasoning ability. Choosing wisely and using multiple models concurrently through Cursor 2.0’s multi‑agent interface increases throughput and yields diverse solutions.
how_to_apply: For quick autocompletions and simple refactors, use small, fast models (Tab, Sonnet 3.x).
Use larger models (GPT‑4o, Claude Sonnet 4.5) for architecture changes or code understanding tasks that require deeper reasoning.
In the multi‑agent interface, run tasks across different models and agents (up to eight). Compare their proposed solutions and select or merge the best parts.

steps: Assign a small model to scaffold boilerplate and type definitions.
Run a mid‑size model to implement the core logic and handle edge cases.
Use a large model to audit and improve architecture, generating tests and documentation.
Compare outputs and apply the most robust solution.
usage_example.expected_outcome: Development speed improves without sacrificing quality, and the chosen solution benefits from multiple perspectives.

caveats: Switching models can reset chat context
Running many agents uses more compute and tokens

items.practice: Establish governance and metrics for Cursor usage through versioned conventions, custom commands and CI integration.
items.why_it_matters: Scaling Cursor across a team requires consistent guidelines and accountability. Governance structures and metrics ensure that AI suggestions improve productivity without degrading quality.
how_to_apply: Create a repository of shared conventions and rules (style guides, allowed modifications) and keep it under version control.
Develop custom slash commands to standardise workflows (e.g., run linters, apply rules, generate PR descriptions).

Integrate Cursor into your CI/CD pipeline: run automated code review via CLI on pull requests, track metrics such as generation time, suggestion acceptance rate, and set up pre‑commit hooks to abort commits on critical issues.

usage_example.context: Onboarding a new team to use Cursor for a microservice architecture.
steps: Create conventions.md with architecture decisions and place it in the repo along with `.cursorrules`.
Write a custom command `/setup-service` that scaffolds a new service with tests and docs based on the conventions.
Configure a GitHub Action that runs `cursor review` on pull requests and posts results. Monitor metrics monthly and adjust rules accordingly.
usage_example.expected_outcome: Team members follow consistent workflows; automated reviews catch issues early and metrics inform continuous improvement.

caveats: Requires time to set up and maintain governance
Overly rigid conventions may stifle creativity
